Iraq. The differences weren't personal, Donald Rumsfeld said. He recalled receiving a book that Henry Kissinger had written, with the inscription, "To an occasional adversary and a permanent friend." When I started working on the book, Henry Kissinger said, "You tell it like it was.' We differed on some issues, and there"s nothing wrong with that. It was professional and healthy, Donald Rumsfeld said. Working on the book meant second-guessing his memory. Donald Rumsfeld also has several complaints about message. He contends it was a mistake for the administration, after finding no WMDs in Iraq, to shift to speaking more about implanting democracy as a rationale for the war. Condoleezza Rice seemed to be the one top advisor who spoke that way, he writes, "but it was not clear to me whether she was encouraging the Dick Cheney to use rhetoric about democracy or whether it was originating with the Dick Cheney ."
